thread.title: Rochester man pleads guilty to killing comic collector
thread.title_full: Rochester man pleads guilty to killing comic collector

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Rochester man pleads guilty to killing comic collector
text:
A Rochester man pleaded guilty Thursday in federal court to a felony murder charge. Donald R. Griffin, 37, pleaded guilty to committing a murder in aid of a racketeering enterprise before U.S. District Judge Richard A. Arcara, the U.S. Attorney's Office said. The charge carries a penalty of life in prison and a fine of $250,000.
Griffin will be sentenced at 1 p.m. Feb. 3.
According to Assistant U.S. Attorney Anthony M. Bruce, Griffin was one of three individuals who broke into the Medina home of 78-year-old Homer Marciniak early July 5, 2010.
They allegedly wanted to steal Marciniak's collection of comic books. The U.S. Attorney's Office estimate their value at $30,000, but previous estimates have been as high as $100,000.
Marciniak woke up and encountered the three individuals in the hallway. Griffin reportedly struck Marciniak in the face, causing cuts.
The three individuals left and Marciniak was taken by ambulance to Medina Memorial Hospital, where his injuries were treated. Marciniak was released from the hospital, but he died a short time later after going into cardiac arrest.
The government was prepared to show at trial that the blow Griffin struck and emotional trauma from the burglary led to Marciniak's death.
Rico Vendetti of Irondequoit, the former owner of East Side Gold and Audio Pawn Shop and Al's Green Tavern on North Goodman Street, engineered the burglary. He pleaded guilty in December 2014 of racketeering influenced corrupt organization, or RICO, and is awaiting sentencing.
Terry Stewart and Brandon Meade were also convicted in connection with this case.
The two other individuals charged in the burglary were Juan Javier and Albert Parsons. Javier, who was a juvenile at the time of the burglary, was convicted of robbery in Orleans County Court. Parsons will be tried in federal court, along with co-defendants Arlene Combs and Dayon Shaver, on Dec. 8.
WCLEVELAND@Gannett.com
